intro: Chersodoma ovopedata, commonly known as the red sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and thrives in full sun, making it well adapted to arid environments. Its showy, pink to red flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Chersodoma ovopedata is also known for its drought tolerance and ability to reseed itself, contributing to its ecological significance in desert ecosystems.
